message: hahaha
I'm embarrassed to wear those stupid goggles even in a movie theater where *everyone* is wearing them

I also think one of the things that set Avatar apart is the *subtlety* of its 3D.  I mean, so many sites are so gaudy with the 3D and they call attention to the fact that it's 3D, whereas Avatar was almost apologetic, and let it be much more subdued.
and by sites I mean movies
http://blogmaverick.com/2011/02/08/the-most-interesting-thing-about-this-years-super-bowl/
"That shit lives forever….."
i read an interesting article by a really famous cinematographer explaining why 3D simply doesn't work
@djchall link?
or, if it does work, it makes the brain incredibly tired because it goes against millions of years of evolution
uh... let's see if i can dig it up
@leah http://blogs.suntimes.com/ebert/2011/01/post_4.html?_r=true
yeah, i have glasses too
i saw AVATAR in theater with 3d, and I was like "the 3d was awesome"
than i watched it at home on DVD and realized that, really, it was the incredible detail of the world-building and visual effects
it would have been just as awesome without the 3d

Yeah, that was a good article. More realistically, I wear glasses and those fucking 3D things piss me off after about 30 minutes. Watching TV with them while I do something like hack on a laptop is just a non-starter
I would've preferred to see it without 3d. But mostly because the 3d was subtle and the glasses became uncomfortable after about an hour
I said subtle first
And by first I mean, I agree
i'd just like hollywood to hurry up with the whole holodeck thing
i want to live inside of AVATAR
in a completely passive way, that doesn't involve any danger
In other news, Daniel Tosh is high larious
i will bet any amount of money that the day the holodeck becomes affordable is the day the human race ceases to accomplish anything
I've been meaning to read this: http://www.amazon.com/Reality-Broken-Games-Better-Change/dp/1594202850
and to think I'm going to miss Andy Clark's lecture tomorrow
well now I feel old thanks @djchall
The 2nd two are good too, except trininities death scene (spoiler alert)
i mean, why deal with exploring the universe, where it's so difficult to get anywhere (even a moon)
keanu reeves apparently dropped hints about that at some talk he was giving
*i am deeply skeptical
and one theory is that they eventually reach a level of technology that they blow themselves up
but i think actually what happens is that they reach a point where they can create virtual realities
which are so utterly compelling that dealing with the real world seems much less interesting
when you could invent a universe with ftl drives and all kinds of neat stuff
church
here being the East Bay, which I'm not actually in anymore, but still
the best part is that they're set in chicago :)
@zac i was thinking recently about the.... paradox whose name i can't remember, but basically the question is, if there are so many planets that are inhabitable and could have intelligent life
why don't they communicate with us
yeah, i mean, assuming you are at all idealist in your philosophy, whats the difference?
we have enough people already who trade success in the real world for that in virtual worlds like WoW cause its more compelling to them
@zac yeah.. the amazing thing is that in the matrix it's portrayed as slavery
and yet, if some quasi omnipotent super-computer offered people that life, they would probably take it
actually, there was that guy in the movie who did take it, but he was portrayed as a villain
wow, the matrix was released twelve years ago in a month
or to put it another way, the twelve year anniversary of the release of the matrix is in march
@alex you mean the matrix sequels?
theres been word they may be making a new one
yeah, i read about that.... deeply skeptical
Holy shit, did I really see the matrix 8 years ago?
It feels so recent.
I just re-watched the matrix... still good.
best part about the Matrix movies is how much of it was filmed around here
like the animatrix short that takes place in a high school, the high school is directly based on Alameda High
